Award.AbstractNarration:
The Promote-Retain-Invest in Science and Mathematics (PRISM) Women Scholars Program is designed to:
(a) Attract current and future students to science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) disciplines.
(b) Improve educational opportunities for undergraduate women pursuing STEM majors.
(c) Increase retention of STEM majors to degree achievement.
(d) Improve student support programs for women pursuing STEM careers.

The program is aimed at encouraging high academic achievement, promoting research and internship opportunities, encouraging outreach and community service, and preparing recipients for careers and/or continued studies in STEM-related fields. The program also encourages recipients to network with their peers, provide and receive peer mentoring support, and engage in high quality group learning activities. The ultimate goal is to develop well-rounded and highly-skilled STEM graduates who are prepared to meet the national need for more American scientists, engineers, and mathematicians.

Intellectual Merit: The program benefits women who are pursuing majors in biology, chemistry, computational mathematics, mathematics, and statistics and actuarial mathematics, and/or completing the requirements for the dual degree program in engineering in conjunction with the University of Notre Dame. The college is using S-STEM grant funds to provide ten scholarships in each of two cohorts for students entering their sophomore year. Scholarship recipients continue to receive support from the program through the remainder of their undergraduate career, provided they maintain academic and social good standing and make acceptable progress toward the completion of their degree. For the 20 recipients, the scholarships provide financial support, as well as opportunities to gain valuable research experience, and to interact with mentors and other professionals in their field.

Broader Impact: The program emphasizes the priorities of integrating teaching and research, promoting diversity, and encouraging scientific understanding that benefits society. It helps produce students well prepared to succeed in fields where women have traditionally been underrepresented by helping to develop individuals capable of meeting the national need for more American scientists and engineers.

Institution.Name: St Mary's College
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: CORPORATION OF SAINT MARY'S COLLEGE, NOTRE DAME, THE

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The NSF S-STEM PRISM Scholarship project supported talented students who will explore and advance the frontiers of the STEM fields. Support was given in the areas of scholarship, academic programming, special funding opportunities, and professional development.

  • The PRISM scholarship offered students the opportunity to obtain a quality education in a STEM field at a nationally ranked institution. Scholarship monies were awarded to 31 students. Of these, only five decided not to pursue a STEM major and thus did not receive further scholarship funds. Two were later awarded Clare Boothe Luce Scholarships, making them ineligible for the NSF funding.
  • Academic programming supported the advancement of the participants’ (hereafter called Scholars) understanding of their respective STEM fields and the possibilities within those fields. The PI and Co-PI (hereafter called PIs) organized and advertised lectures in the STEM areas. These lectures exposed students to current research in their disciplines. In an exit survey, the Scholars reported that they learned about the breadth of the STEM disciplines, the collaboration among STEM professionals, and the professional opportunities within STEM through these academic lectures. Faculty mentors and lecturers encouraged the Scholars to explore research and industrial opportunities. All performed research at Saint Mary’s College and/or at other institutions as part of their Senior Comprehensive (thesis) and several engaged in summer industrial internships. Through these experiences, the Scholars were able to enhance their resumes, immerse themselves in the profession, network with professionals, and develop their own career plans.
  • Each Scholar could obtain funding for research or professional development and travel. About half of the Scholars received funds to purchase consumables for experiments, to obtain study materials for professional exams, and to pay for graduate school examination or application fees. Most Scholars used the funds available for conference travel. These Scholars found the conferences to be inspiring as they learned about opportunities and current advances in their fields and made connections with others in their field. Some Scholars gave oral or poster presentations at professional meetings. 
  • The STEM Professional Development Workshop, funded by the grant and led (mostly) by alumnae who are STEM professionals, addressed career skills specific to the STEM disciplines. The Scholars helped in the planning and hosting the daylong workshop aimed at the entire STEM community of our college. Workshop sessions addressed essential soft skills, gender bias, interviewing, and resume writing, and included mock interviews and networking opportunities. This workshop was very successful in meeting not only the goals of educating students about the professional skills but also in demonstrating the importance of professional connections and facilitating those connections between current students and professionals.

Broader Impacts: The work of STEM professionals impacts our lives in significant ways: they produce new medicines, technologies, models of the environment, etc. that can improve the situation of all societies. The more we can assist those who wish to pursue a STEM discipline, the greater the possibility of bettering the health and welfare of all societies. This grant supported students who expressed an interest in STEM and encouraged them to complete their degrees and seek employment or further study in a STEM field. Moreover, with this grant, the PIs sought to serve a broader audience and increase the pool of future STEM students. The PIs organized two panels, led by the Scholars, on the topics of pursuing a STEM discipline and on obtaining an internship or REU. These panels were very well attended and impactful. Additionally, the Scholars served others through leadership and mentoring, key factors in keeping women in the STEM fields. In an exit survey, Scholars reported that networking with other STEM students, faculty, alumnae, and professionals, mentoring younger students, and leading workshops (greatly) enhanced their pursuit of a STEM discipline. Recognizing the importance of mentorship, some Scholars served as tutors for 6-12 grade and college students while others served as resident or teaching assistants. All Scholars participated in science outreach activities that encouraged girls and young women to pursue STEM studies and careers. In these roles, Scholars have led or taught sessions exposing middle-school students to STEM topics, judged science fairs, and proctored math tests for high school students. Altogether, this grant served not only those receiving scholarships but also prospective STEM students by providing information and by serving as role models.  

Summary: The grant successfully contributed to the education and professional development of women who are passionate about the STEM disciplines, who will advance the discipline, who will mentor other people in the STEM disciplines, and who will be future leaders in STEM. All Scholars have or will earn bachelor’s degrees and have or will pursue graduate study or industrial careers in STEM areas. Most importantly, all will “pay it forward” by continued leadership and service to younger women in STEM.
